reviewText: It is becoming more and more obvious that Europeans walked on North American soil long before Columbus "discovered" the New World in 1492 - and not just the Vikings.  The clues have been here for centuries, but only in recent years have enough of them been discovered to make even the staunchest of doubters take pause.  While the Holy Grail does play a part in this documentary, Holy Grail in America is really about a secret history of America and the men involved in that history - primarily the Knights Templar, Norsemen, and Cistercian monks, who seem to have left their indelible mark here in the 14th  century.The centerpiece to this story is the Kensington Rune stone, which was uncovered by rural Minnesota farmer Olof Ohman in 1898.  The stone, wrapped within the roots of a tree, was covered by mysterious runic inscriptions that - once translated - date the writing to 1362.  For years, most experts accused Ohman of perpetrating a hoax, but new scientific (particularly geological) studies point to the stone and its inscriptions dating back to the 14th century.  If you're thinking Minnesota is a long way from the Atlantic Ocean, I would point out that there are two different routes by which visitors could have sailed to reach that general area.  The provenance of the mysterious Scandinavian runes themselves has been reinforced by more recent discoveries bearing similar markings - e.g., the Spirit Pond rune stones discovered in Maine in 1971, the Narragansett rune stone in Rhode Island, and the Westford Boat Stone in Massachusetts.  One common link that exists between these various stones is the inclusion of a Hooked X in the inscriptions, and this is one piece of evidence that points to the Knights Templar.  Indeed, the remarkable architecture of the Newport Tower in Rhode Island and the Westford Knight stone in Massachusetts support the claim that Prince Henry Sinclair sailed to North America in 1398.  This followed the period in which the Knights Templar had been driven out of Europe, with some taking refuge in Scotland.  If Templars had already journeyed to the New World, where better to hide the Templar treasure than in a land completely unknown to the papal forces seeking to stamp out the Templar order?  If the Templars had indeed discovered the Holy Grail during the Crusades, one has to consider the idea that it may still lie undiscovered somewhere in America or Canada (perhaps even in the Oak Island Money Pit).The Holy Grail portion of this story (including speculation as to the actual nature and identity of the Holy Grail itself) is, of course, conjecture, but this documentary puts together a growing string of facts that place the Knights Templar in the New World over a century before the Nina, Pinta, and Santa Maria ever left Portugal.  Naturally, there are still numerous and quite vocal critics who dismiss all of the evidence out of hand as products of a hoax, but anyone with an open mind cannot help but be fascinated by all of the information presented in this truly impressive documentary.  (It's a detailed and complicated story, much of which I cannot even begin to touch upon in the context of this review.)  The Kensington Rune stone and the various rune stones recently discovered in New England may well force the history of America to be rewritten - and not by Dan Brown.
summary: Makes a compelling case for the presence of Templars in pre-Columbian North America

reviewText: I usually don't give one star, like others may do just for not liking it, but this is a prime example of shows like these on the History Channel that makes it seem that they are a joke, and considering the other shows that they have on here (Ax Men, Ancient Aliens, etc.), it proves that their focal point is on entertaiment for the lowest common denominator, not to educate.I remember watching this program several months ago (8 months probably), and wondered how true this was, but didn't bother researching. Around 4-5 months ago, I randomly became very interested in the Middle Ages, thanks to another program that was shown on THC. I've been reading for months from numerous sources on this era practically everyday. This program happened to be on the History Channel again, and I couldn't help but notice all of the lies that were mentioned on that program. To the general viewer who is ignorant of the Middle Ages as a whole, they could actually fall victim to believing this. This show had an obvious bias and tried to make it balanced by having one guy attempt to rebutt with Authors of the Knights Templar fantasy books, Desendants of Sinclair and of the founder of the Runestone, and Scott Wolter. The majority of these people were not qualified to do a discussion like this, and I don't recall them having anyone in a specific field of expertise speaking against these theories. Not to mention they had the narrator, Liev Schrieber speak on this, and he seem to believe it as well.Unlike most people who generally give one stars without listing reasons (No better than five-star reviewers who do the same), I'll tell you what they had wrong. One was Robert the Bruce. Bruce was never linked to the Templar, and one of those authors said that the Knights Templar saved the Scots from the English during the battle of Bannockburn. I've read from several sources of the battle, and not one mentoined anything about the Knights Templar. However, there was a poem during Victorian era England called 'Bruce Legend' of the Templar saving Bruce and the Scots, and this is where that author more than likely got his idea from. Bruce did want his heart buried in the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem, but the Templar wasn't involved. The carrier of his heart never got past Granada, as the protecter of the heart died in battle while fighting along with the Castilians, and soldiers eventually found both he and his heart and returned it to Scotland. There is this Fantasy book series (Templar and the Stone, and Templar and the Crown) that did link Bruce to the Knights, but it's fantasy and shouldn't be taken as anything else.Second was the Templar brought back the archectiture from the Holy land and the Gothic structures that still stand in Europe was from them. Not true. For Example, the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris was the first of its kind to use flying buttressess, and they didn't get that directly from the Levant. What the Christians did get from fighting in the Crusades, and moreso from places in the Muslims and Jews in Spain, was Aristotle, the math and astronomy, and other sciences from there to help further themselves in Christian Europe. There were specialized translators (such as Gerard of Cremona) who help translate these works that the Arabs got from the Greeks, that help lead to their advancement in engineering and before the Renaissance.Third major issue was the Friday the 13th situation. They do not give any background to the issue. If they did, they would be at fault of their presentation. Philip the IV of France had a longoing struggle with the Papacy, mainly Pope Boniface VIII. Philippe le Bel (Philip the Fair) was heavily taxing the clergy, and attempted to make the taxes permanent for the support of the crusades. Boniface issues two bulls against him, and le Bel still went about heavily taxing others. Boniface threatened le Bel with excommunication after the arrest of a bishop, and he siezed Boniface and held him captive. Boniface was freed eventually, but died soon afterwards. After the short reign of Benedict XI, Philip helped engineer the election of Clement V as pope, and had the home of the Papacy moved from Rome to Avignon, in France, by the end of the first decade of the 14th century (1309). Before the move, however, le Bel was in debt to several groups of people, among those the Jews, the Lombards, and the Templar. He siezed the Templar and had the majority of those he could find torchered and killed, and they confessed to crimes they didn't commit. But they presented it as they actually did these crimes. Clement V was a puppet for Philippe le Bel and used it as an inquisition for reasoning to for persecuting not only the Templars, but the Jews and the Lombards. The trails and persecutions of the Templar didn't come to a halt in France until 1314, yet their retreat from persecution didn't occur until 1362. And they didn't face persecution in the Iberian Peninsula, or Scotland. The average person watching this wouldn't know that, though.Fourth was Columbus. Another conspiracy theory of Columbus and his sailing to the New World. The only other negative reviewer to date did mention pretty much what I would have said of it. Columbus went in a total different loaction of where Sinclair supposedly went, in order to find the Holy Grail. And there would be no need of the Templars to go to America to avoid persecution over 100 years later. The Spainards and Portuguese just finished desposing the last of the Moors in Granada in 1492, the same year he sailed to the New World. Or a search for a Holy Grail, when it was clearly the Ottoman Empire who blocked the original trade route, and they had to find a new one.Considering all of these errors made (even some people saying  that Sinclair had no link to the Templar, that I don't know for certain, and certainly that's not mentioned on this film) that were mentioned in minor detail compared to other parts, why should you trust something like this when they can't even get these facts right? Because they have an agenda to push. And considering the majority of us Americans could care less about reading, and more about being entertained, they will believe something like this instead of doing some research for themselves. This is why I feel that History is important, and should be treated as such. So people won't fall victim to pseudo-historians and conspiracy theorists and be well read not to fall for this and shows like it (Theories presented as fact). Their range of exploring 'facts' was way too narrow to be taken seriously here. This belongs on a channel like Sci-fi, and not the History Channel. But people will think that just because it's the 'History' Channel, they must be right. They didn't even have Middle Age Historians in specific fields of knowledge for the show, and the best qualified person on this show couldn't identify everything for certain, or he wasn't qualified for to make some his comments on other issues. The lack of objectivity is obvious, and so was their attempt of trying to be balanced. This is what usually happens when you try to mix entertainment with history: fabrications and falsified information. If you wanted to believe this, or if you were a skeptic, you probably would/could believe it, but if you're truthfully knowledgeable of this era, you shouldn't. Shame on the History Channel for endorsing this utter nonsense, but this shouldn't be a surprise....
Title: N/A

reviewText: With "Holy Grail" in the title and the Templars on the cover, one wonders if this will be another wild-nonsensical-wild-jumps-in-imagination theories about the Templars. Surprisingly it is not one of those and is much about precolumbus voyages to America - such as the Vikings - as it is about Templars. The key tieing everything together are the runic inscriptions found in New England and the Midwest. So Vikings figure in here somewhere to some degree. For decades, people ignored Viking evidence and even after their settlement in Canada was found, many still scoffed at the idea. But did these world explorers go no further? Did others follow their lead? Have we been ignoring evidences for no good reason other than they are inconvienent to our other theories? This show is a great primer to these subjects and for the most part ignores the bizarre theories many have attached to the Templars. We are now seeing a great shift in what occured here prior to 1492 and its no longer the realm of oddball theorists. See alsoChristopher Columbus, the Last Templar,The Templars: The Secret History Revealed,Templars in America: From the Crusades to the New World&Vikings in America.
summary: Surprisingly Detailed Look at Pre-Columbus Explorers

reviewText: This is an excellent look at the history of the Knights Templar, the Holy Grail, and the involvement of the Sinclair family members.  I purchased three of them - one for each of our sons. The Da Vinci Code provided a fictional account - using Rosslyn Chapel.  This film provided insight to other possibilities.  I highly recommend this interesting video.
